def_1: The letter A in Visayan is pronounced as in Spanish, except when it has a cut short, abrupt sound, which can be learned only by hearing

ex_2_english: Oh, it is you, that have come.
ex_3: A, bayái (pabayái) lang ang mga bátà dirâ.
ex_3_english: Well, leave the children there alone.
ex_5_english: Why, don’t take any notice of it.

def_1: A suf?x of verbs that have a passive in - on.
compare: búhat, buháton, higúgma, higugmaón, táhud, tahúron, tahúdon, túman, tumánon, umá, úmhon, ísip, isípon, pa, tíndog, tindogón
notes:
This suf?x occurs in the following tenses:
1.) The passive impersonal imperative.
Buháta iní. Do this. (búhat, buháton).
Higugmaá kag tahúra (—úda) ang ímo
ginikánan. Love and respect your parents,
(higúgma, higugmaón; táhud, tahúron,
tahúdon).
2.) The passive negative past. Walâ níya
pagbuháta iní. He did not do this. Walâ ni
la pagtumána ang íla katungdánan. They
have not ful?lled their duties, (túman,
tumánon).
3.) The passive negative present. Sa karón
walâ na níya pagaúmha iníng bánglid. He
now no longer tills this slope, (umá,
úmhon).
Tungúd sang kadamuón sang íla
mga páhò, walâ na níla pagaisípa, kóndì
ginasokób na lang sa pasungán. Owing to
the great quantity of their mangoes they no
longer count them, but measure them by
the bushel. (ísip, isípon).
Ngáa man nga
walâ mo pagapatindogá ang halígi? Why
are you not setting up the post? (pa,
tíndog, tindogón).

def_1: An exclamation of sorrow, anguish or the like.
ex_1: A-a, kon amó inâ ang pangabúhî, maáyo na lang nga mamatáy akó!
ex_1_english: Ah, if life is such, it would be better for me to die!
ex_2: A-a, ano na man iní! Maanó na lang akó!
ex_2_english: Alas, what does this mean! What shall I do now!

def_1: Pooh! Whew! Foh! Faugh! Now then! Fie!
ex_1_english: Don’t touch that. Keep off. Pooh, it’s ?lthy! Now then, keep away from that.

ex_1: Abá, ang íya sinâ nga katahúm!

ex_1_english: Ah, is it really true? Can it be so?
ex_2: Nabáton ko ang isá ka makalilípay nga balítà—Abâ?
ex_2_english: I have received some joyful news.—Have you, really?

def_2: The breast of a bird, especially of a fowl
def_3: To carry on the back, put on the back.
ex_1: Ibutáng mo iníng bayóong sa abá sang karabáw.
ex_1_english: Put this bag on the buffalo’s back.
ex_2_english: Chop up the breast of the chicken.
ex_3: Ginpaabá akó níya sa pagtabók sa subâ.
ex_3_english: He carried me on his back across the river.
ex_4_english: Get hold of his back. Grasp him behind by the shoulders.
compare: likód, talúdtud, dúghan, pétso, tíbong, patíbong

def_1: To eat or bite off a piece
def_2: To undermine and carry off, wash away (of water)
ex_1: Ab-abá lang ang tinápay kag ang mabilin nga inab-abán ihátag mo sa ímo mánghud.
ex_1_english: Just bite off a piece of bread, and give the remainder to your younger brother (sister).
ex_2: May katalágman nga ab-abón sang subâ ang pángpang.
ex_2_english: There is danger that the river will undermine and carry off its banks.
ex_3: Indì mo pag-ipaáb-ab ang kárne sa idô.
ex_3_english: Do not let the dog snap at the meat.

compare: baláy nga ginapúy-an sang mga práyle nga benediktíno ukón sang mga mádre nga benediktínas

def_2: To shoulder, carry on the shoulder
ex_1: Dálha lang iní sa abága mo or abagáha lang ini.
ex_2: Malápad ang íya abága or malápad siá sing abága.

def_1: One with strong or broad shoulders

ex_1_english: The rain pours down at short intervals, one shower or squall following another in quick succession.
notes: abákabák which is more in use

ex_1: Panápton nga abaká, kalát nga abaká, etc.

def_1: To follow in succession one thing close upon another, chase each other, come one behind the other.
ex_1: Abáw, nagaalabák-abák gid lámang ang mga nagasalákà.
ex_1_english: Why, visitors are coming up one behind the other (in great numbers).
ex_2: Nagaabák-abák gid karón ang íla mga kalisúd.
ex_2_english: At present their dif?culties are following one upon another or their troubles overtake one another.

def_1: One who has plenty of—, is rich in—, hemp
def_2: Containing hemp-plants, suitable for a hemp-plantation
ex_1_english: A hill covered with hemp-plants or suitable for growing hemp.
ex_2_english: He is wealthy or in?uential, because he owns large hemp-plantations.

def_1: A small ?sh of a reddish colour.
